image.altText: Nusantara presentation in Singapore

items.synopsis: Joko Widodo heads home from Sydney with a promise of more assistance from Australia towards his legacy plan of building a new capital city on the island of Borneo.

title.children: Jokowi is shopping around the world for investment in Indonesia's new city – but potential backers aren't buying

image.altText: Two professional cricket players speak to each other on a pitch.

items.synopsis: English cricketers bristle at suggestions they have had a 'Bazbawl' over the second Test, as former captain Joe Root says any suggestion Jonny Bairstow has tried for the same stumping as Alex Carey is incorrect.

title.children: Root attacks Australia as Head lays Bairstow's hypocrisy bare

image.altText: Philip Lowe sitting at a desk behind a microphone mid-sentence, gesturing with his right hand and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Australian home borrowers are experiencing much, much more interest rate pain than borrowers in New Zealand, Canada, the UK or US – for one simple reason, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: The simple reason why Australian mortgage borrowers are in more pain than those in other countries

image.altText: An illustration of artists JK-47, Alex Lahey and Sarah Blasko

items.synopsis: More than 840 cover songs have been played in the triple j studios across 20 years. The data shows us how artists craft a cover song.

title.children: Some of the world's biggest songs are covers. What makes a good one?

image.altText: Against a dark background, an older woman is seen from behind turning her face to the side, with serious expression.

items.synopsis: With reports of elder abuse on the rise in Australia, these women in their 80s are sharing their stories in the hope that others seek the help they need.

title.children: It took years for Francene to realise she was being abused by a relative. Now 81, she's taken a stand

image.altText: 'Walk together to a better future': Linda Burney responds to the Liberal Party's opposition to the Voice

items.synopsis: Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney will name four priorities for the proposed Voice to Parliament in a speech to the National Press Club today, after growing pressure to detail how it would benefit First Nations people.

title.children: Linda Burney says gaps in health and education are among key priorities for the Voice

image.altText: Britain's Kate, Princess of Wales, left, stands in the royal box with tennis champion Roger Federer and his wife Mirka.

items.synopsis: The Princess of Wales is among Wimbledon spectators giving Roger Federer a standing ovation of almost two minutes as the retired tennis star enters the Royal Box on Centre Court.

title.children: 'Inspiration, icon, legend': Wimbledon farewells Federer with tribute and standing ovation

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses and a jacket walks with a folder tucked under her arm.

items.synopsis: The daughter of Western Australia racing legend Fred Kersley is found guilty of possessing stolen or unlawfully obtained property after $250,000 was found at her home.

title.children: WA racing identity Kellie Kersley found guilty of possessing illegal cash allegedly linked to bikie

image.altText: A young woman with pink hair faces news microphones with two people in dark clothes behind her.

items.synopsis: A Perth family is desperate for answers after their one-year-old daughter died days after they say she was sent home by a GP. WARNING: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that this article contains an image of a person who has died, used with the permission of their family.

title.children: Health service says baby who died in Perth hospital received ‘timely and appropriate clinical care’

image.altText: A composite of Ash Barty and her newborn baby.

items.synopsis: Former world number one tennis player Ash Barty has announced the birth of her first child, Hayden.

title.children: 'Our beautiful boy': Australian tennis great Ash Barty gives birth to son

image.altText: A man dressed in fire gear watches an burnt and smoky horizon near sunset.

items.synopsis: The World Meteorological Organization has declared the first El Niño eight years after the last weather event developed, bringing record-high temperatures.

title.children: High global temperatures and disruptive weather likely as international weather agency declares El Niño

image.altText: A woman covered in blue paint speaks on the phone on a hospital bed.

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin will be briefed about the beating of a Russian journalist and lawyer in Chechnya, the Kremlin said, describing a serious attack that required an energetic response.

title.children: 'Gun to my head': Russian reporter kidnapped in Chechnya, with Putin to be briefed

image.altText: A Palestinian holds a flag in front of a fire.

items.synopsis: Israel is close to completing its raid in Jenin, after the fiercest fighting in the flashpoint West Bank town in more than two decades, which has left 10 Palestinians dead and forced thousands to flee.

title.children: Eight injured in Tel Aviv attack, as Israel's operation in Jenin nears completion

image.altText: Piglets crowd together in a pen looking towards the camera

items.synopsis: The government confirms animal welfare inspectors have attended a Wheatbelt piggery in response to a developing animal welfare situation.

title.children: Authorities investigate mass pig deaths at WA property

image.altText: A young man and woman standing together in front of a light plane.

items.synopsis: A transport safety investigation into a plane crash that killed a newlywed couple and their unborn child in North Queensland earlier this year finds that the pilot had completed the practical requirements to obtain a licence but not the flight or theory tests.

title.children: Investigation finds pilot was unlicensed during fatal plane crash that killed young couple in poor weather

image.altText: The police divers boat at the Rockhampton boat ramp

items.synopsis: Thieves allegedly broke into the Victorian family's caravan, stole their car keys, went on a joy-ride through Rockhampton, then dumped their vehicle in the Fitzroy River.

title.children: Police divers to retrieve $300k vehicle dumped among 'the crocodiles' after alleged theft from holiday makers

image.altText: An image of the Reserve bank sign in Martin Place, Sydney

items.synopsis: The bank's board says the decision to keep the rate at 4.1 per cent will give it time to assess the state of the economy, but warns that the good news may not last for long.

title.children: Reserve Bank delivers a reprieve for mortgage holders, but more hikes could be coming

image.altText: The outline of a woman, obscured, in front of a sign for Mindil Beach

items.synopsis: A coroner hears several pieces of evidence against a man who beat his wife to death were ruled inadmissible before he pleaded guilty to a downgraded charge of manslaughter, having previously been charged with murder.

title.children: 'Defective' evidence against killer ruled inadmissible before charge downgraded, DV inquest hears

image.altText: A male wearing a surgical mask walks past a metal fence holding the straps of his backpack

items.synopsis: A court hears former lawyer Dev Manon "was not motivated by greed" but was a key figure in the scheme to defraud the ATO of $105 million.

title.children: Corrupt lawyer jailed for 14 years over $105m Plutus Payroll tax fraud

image.altText: A blonde woman sits in front of a microphone and looks up with a serious expression, wearing a floral blouse

items.synopsis: A Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman has called the attack, which disrupted flight operations at Moscow's major airport, "yet another act of terrorism".

title.children: 'Act of terrorism': Russia accuses Ukraine of another drone attack on Moscow

image.altText: Tanks full of contaminated water are seen at the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear plant in Japan

items.synopsis: Japan says the water is safe and needs to be released so the plant can be decommissioned but China, South Korea and Pacific countries are opposing the operation, which could take 40 years.

title.children: UN says Japan can dump treated radioactive water from Fukushima power plant into ocean

image.altText: A composite image of two men of Chinese appearance.

items.synopsis: Two men living in Australia have criticised a move by Hong Kong authorities to issue them with arrest warrants under a controversial national security law, putting a $HK1 million bounty on their heads.

title.children: Adelaide man says warrant for his arrest in Hong Kong shows China is 'more a threat than a friend to the world'

image.altText: Power lines at sunrise in the Perth suburb of Treeby.

items.synopsis: Federal Energy Minister Chris Bowen seeks to head off growing community opposition to transmission lines, launching an inquiry into how projects are planned.

title.children: There's a growing community backlash to transmission line projects. This review hopes to quell concerns

image.altText: Jennifer Board smelling a sunflower in a field.

items.synopsis: A court has heard the details surrounding the death of a young aspiring police officer in Townsville.

title.children: Dash-cam evidence from scene of fatal crash was removed and destroyed, court hears

image.altText: An elderly woman with glasses smiling with a flower border. An elderly man with glasses smiling.

items.synopsis: A woman related to a 94-year-old woman and her husband, who died in hospital a year apart, has now been charged with two counts of murder after she was arrested earlier today, SA police say.

title.children: Female relative charged with murders of couple, both 94, who died a year apart

image.altText: vets in scrubs carrying animal carriers

items.synopsis: Nearly 30 dogs and puppies have been seized by the RSPCA from a rural property in the Macedon Ranges after a tip-off about alleged illegal dog breeding.

title.children: Puppy farm raid seizes labradors, golden retrievers found in 'cramped and unsanitary conditions'

image.altText: Police officers in red helmets and wet suits walk through fast moving water in a forest

items.synopsis: Search crews secured to ropes wade through fast-moving water at a Tasmanian waterfall near where Belgian tourist Celine Cremer is believed missing, but fail to find any sign of her.

title.children: Search of fast-moving waters fails to locate Celine Cremer

image.altText: A picture of the outside of a workplace in Epping.

items.synopsis: The 46-year-old employee, Daryn Raines, was fatally crushed while operating a turret punch — a large piece of moving machinery used in the production of perforated metal — at a Melbourne factory in February 2021.

title.children: Manufacturing company fined for 'obvious' safety risk that led to crushing death of worker

image.altText: A sign for Woolworths on top of another for Coles

items.synopsis: The SA government is proposing to introduce a law that would make it illegal for anyone charged or convicted of child sex offences to work alongside children, after a man convicted of possessing child exploitation material continued to work at a supermarket.

title.children: Child-sex offenders to be banned from all SA workplaces employing children

image.altText: A person takes a photo as a full moon known as the "Buck Moon" rises behind the Temple of Poseidon, in Cape Sounion, near Athens

items.synopsis: Don't stress if the cloudy weather locked you out of last night's supermoon — there's three more before the end of the year.

title.children: Clouds blocked the buck supermoon for many in Australia, so here are photos of it from around the world
